titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust Records, 1975-2000 CTC.2000.02
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by William Daw.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-09-14T14:50-0400

did.abstract: The Pittsburgh Cultural Trust was formed in 1984 with the goal of re-establishing an arts and entertainment district downtown. The Benedum Center, Fulton Theater, Harris Theater, and the Wood Street Galleries are all owned and operated by the Cultural Trust. This collection contains the records of the Cultural Trust from 1984 through 1999. Included are marketing materials, financial records, institutional and real estate development, and the production records of the Benedum Center.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: In the early 1970s a group of prominent Pittsburghers led by H.J. Heinz II began an effort to return the Penn and Liberty corridor of downtown to the thriving theater district it once was. This area had been in steady decline since the 1950s. The era of the Nixon, Stanley, Alvin and Pitt theatres had long since passed. They all were demolished, dormant, or in disrepair. The Howard Heinz Endowment funded the renovation of the Loew's Penn Theater in 1967. In 1971, the new Heinz Hall was unveiled as the new home of the Pittsburgh Symphony Society. In 1984, this group officially created the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust with the goal of creating a cultural district in downtown Pittsburgh. Their current mission statement is "to stimulate the economic and cultural development of Pittsburgh through the development and promotion of a downtown arts and entertainment district. The Trust encourages and presents diverse performing and visual arts programs in the Cultural District." The Trust purchased the Stanley Theatre and completely renovated it. It was renamed the Benedum Center for the Performing Arts and was dedicated in 1987. After the $43 million project was completed, the Cultural Trust began to develop other properties in and around Penn and Liberty avenues.

Jack Heinz named Carol Brown as the Trust’s first president in 1986. She served until her retirement in 2001 when Kevin McMahon, former executive vice president of the John F. Kennedy Center, was named as the new president.

The Trust offers assistance and provides services to Pittsburgh local arts community. It organizes free quarterly gallery crawls through the Cultural District, internship opportunities, and student and teacher workshops. Other businesses and organizations located in the Cultural District have joined the Cultural Trust in the revitalization project of the Penn-Liberty Historic District. The Trust has facade restoration grants available to buildings that are within the Cultural District to help improve the overall appearance of the district. The Trust and the city of Pittsburgh have spent millions of dollars on beautification and improvements in the Cultural District.

Due to the theatre renovations, art installations, and other improvements all led to the creation of the Cultural District that was designated a national historic district in 1987. The newest addition to the Cultural District is the O'Reilly Theater and was completed in 1999. The 650 seat theater was designed by Michael Graves and is the home of the Pittsburgh Public Theater.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The records of the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust contain the organization’s office files from the beginning, in 1984, to the opening of the O’Reilly Theater in 1999. The majority of the materials concern the restoration of the Stanley Theatre and its reopening as the Benedum Center for the Performing Arts, the settlement files for every show that performed at the Benedum Center from its opening in 1987 to 1998, the development of the Cultural District between Penn and Liberty avenue, the planning and construction of the O’Reilly Theater, and finally the advertising and marketing information for a majority of the productions presented by the Cultural Trust as well as the marketing of the Trust itself.

The vast majority of the collection are office files, but there are a few other types of materials, including photographs, slides, ledgers, newspaper clippings, and architectural designs. There are very few materials that date before the early eighties.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into eight series:
IV. Harris Theatre / Art Cinema Renovation

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by William Daw between 2006-2009.

did.unittitle: Benedum Center for the Performing Arts,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Benedum Center of the Performing Arts is the primary venue of the Cultural Trust. Most of the Trust’s major presentation programs are performed at the Benedum Center. The information in this series relates to the operational files for the venue and settlement files for all the productions that performed at the theater.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the administrative and operational files of the Benedum Center of the Arts. Included are files concerning the restoration and reopening of the theatre and correspondence with partner arts organizations such as the Civic Light Opera, the Pittsburgh Ballet, and the Pittsburgh Opera.

did.unittitle: Arts in Focus, Ltd. Binocular rental,
Civic Light Opera interest in advance sales,
Civic Light Opera Pittsburgh Symphony correspondence,
Joint management of Pittsburgh Broadway Series,
Joint management of Pittsburgh Broadway Series,

Operations study by University of Pittsburgh students,
Promotional materials for the Benedum Center,
Residents and constituents booking policies and procedures,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a settlement file for every show that played at the Benedum Theater from October 1987 through December 1998. The materials are arranged chronologically by the opening date of the production. Most of the shows were presented by local theatre orgnaizations such as the Pittsburgh Broadway Series, the Pittsburgh Ballet Theatre, the Pittsburgh Dance Council, Pittsburgh Opera, and the Civic Light Opera. Each file folder title lists the production name and, if non-local, the presenter. Occasionally productions that were a part of the Pittsburgh Broadway Series were performed at the Heinz Hall for the Performing Arts, these productions are included and noted as such. Also included are files for shows that were planned, but for some reason or another were cancelled.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists of office files and architectural materials related to the Penn-Liberty Historic District of downtown Pittsburgh. This area, also known as Pittsburgh’s Cultural District, was named to the US Register of Historic Districts in 1987. Primarily contains records on the development and planning of the O'Reilly Theater, the Allegheny Riverfront park, and Theater Square.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The District Development series includes information regarding the many buildings operated by the Cultural Trust and their plans to improve and revitalize the Cultural District. There is a considerable amount of materials detailing the plans for what would become the O'Reilly Theater, Allegheny Riverfront park, and Theater Square. Also included are materials related to the renovations of buildings along Penn Avenue that are in Cultural District. The materials are arranged in alphabetical order by the title of the folder.* Urban Development Action Grant, Urban Redevelopment Authority.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Most of these plans and drawings are centered around the design and construction of the O’Reilly Theatre, Allegheny Riverfront park, and the Theatre Square office building. The plans are arranged in alphabetical order by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The art services branch of the Cultural Trust aimed to advise and support other arts organization in the Pittsburgh area. Most of this material centers around workshops that the Trust organized. The subseries is arranged in alphabetical order by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Arranged in this series is the materials that relate to the renovation of the Art Cinema at 809 Liberty Avenue. The venue was renamed the Harris Theatre after the project was completed in November 1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The fifth series in the collection groups together the files regarding the financial campaigns of the Cultural Trust. The series is split into two subseries. One, contains the records of the yearly campaign and the other all other institutional development office files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These files are arranged chronologically by campaign season and then alphabetically by folder title. The majority of these files contain copies of the letters to individual and corporate donors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of files related to the financial requests by the Cultural Trust to various federal institutions, grant foundations, and development groups. It also contains planning documents for various fundraisers that the Trust organized. The files are arranged alphabetically by folder subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes the office files for the Cultural Trust’s executives, the meeting notes of the Board of Trustees and of the Executive Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Of note in this subseries are several consultant studies done for the Trust, materials relating to the renovation of the Fulton theater, and the preliminary efforts involved in the design and construction of the O'Reilly Theater. Materials are arranged alphabetically by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The board of trustees of the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust meet 4 to 6 times a year, which included a larger annual meeting in March. The files contain meeting agendas, administrative reports, financial reports, newspaper articles, and meeting minutes. These files are arranged in chronological order by meeting date.

did.unittitle: Board of trustees retreat transcript of proceedings,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains bank statements, ledgers, and budget figures. The major accounts covered are from the following departments Administrative, Annual Campaign, Benedum Center, District Development, Fulton Theater, Trust Operating fund, and the Wood Street Galleries. The series is arranged in alphabetical order by the title of the folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The series contains promotional and marketing materials for the Trust's various performing arts series' - the Pittsburgh Broadway Series, Arts Blastoff! Live on Stage, Voices of a New Millennium, the Street Fair, and others. Several productions of the Pittsburgh Broadway Series are more thoroughly documented, these being the Phantom of the Opera, les Miserables, Show Boat, and Miss Saigon. Also within this series are sets of marketing files for most of the productions that were performed between 1989-1999. This series also includes a five year run of newspaper clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These are the marketing department's general office files. Most notable among the files here are the materials relating to the opening and exhibits of the Wood Street Galleries and the joint promotions between the Cultural Trust and the Pittsburgh Downtown Partnership. These files are arranged in alphabetical order by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The newspaper clippings are arranged in two groups. First are clippings that were primarily assembled by a press clipping service. The second group are clippings that were specifically assembled to be distributed during the bi-monthly board meetings of the Cultural Trust.

Arts Blastoff and Live on Stage files,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Arts Blastoff was the original name for the Cultural Trust’s programming series designed for children. The series changed its title to Live on Stage before it’s second season. Each season has files on advertising, promotions, subscription information, ticket sales, etc. These files are in chronological order by season and then alphabetical by folder subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Pittsburgh Broadway Series is the program that brings the national tours of Broadway productions to Pittsburgh. The performances are either held at the Benedum Center or Heinz Hall. The 1989/1990 season through the 1999/2000 season is covered. Each season has folders containing some of the following topics – expenses, marketing, advertising, group sales, subscriptions, brochure design, sponsorship, pricing, etc. The materials are arranged in chronological order by season and then alphabetically by folder subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Cultural Trust’s Street Fair began in 1995 and became an annual late summer early autumn downtown event. The files are in chronological order by year and then alphabetical by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This program series featured a variety of types of performances. From musical concerts, lectures, monologists, etc. The shows usually played at the Byham Theater. The files are arranged chronologically by season and then alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Contained in this series are the production marketing files for several of the Cultural Trusts programs. Most of the productions are from the Pittsburgh Broadway Series, but there also productions from the Live on Stage series and other Trust presentations. Each production may have files on each of the following topics – advertising, expenses, gross potential, press clippings press packet, promotions, settlement, tear sheets (newspaper advertising clippings), and ticket sales. In most cases the advertising files contain information on newsprint, television, and radio. Productions that have a greater amount of files attributed to them are Phantom of the Opera (opened 7/24/1993), Miss Saigon (opened 8/06/1997), Chicago (opened 1/12/1998), Rent (opened 5/25/1998), and Showboat (opened 8/21/1998). The productions are arranged chronologically according to it’s opening.
